Original question: Can anyone learn about Latter-day Saint (LDS) temple work without becoming involved with Mormonism or going to church?

Sure, but your learning will be limited if you do not seek and follow the influence of the Holy Spirit. If you don’t think that talking to people face-to-face is too involved, there are plenty of people who will share first-hand experience with you.

You can visit a FamilySearch Center close to you, but I caution that most of them are located inside a Latter-day Saint meetinghouse, but are not open at the same times as worship services. People there will tell you about temple and family history work. Some (like my late uncle) may not even be members of the Church. You may also visit any of the the visitors centers, most of which are adjacent to a temple. You may be able to attend a rare temple open house.

You will also find tremendous resources on the web site of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and, of course, FamilySearch, which holds an annual convention called RootsTech.

I jest, of cour

Ooh, ooh! I’ve got this.

Behold, my ultimate weapon in conversion. Behold and weep, ye disconsolate!

Okay, I used the Duncan Hines recipe, but it was very similar.

Had enough? Ready to convert? No? Fine. Have a sample of this:

Family size. The horrors!

You stand no chance. Surely, you’re already salivating at the opportunity to talk with me and my companion about the sweet, sweet gospel of Christ and feeling the delicious promptings of the Holy Ghost around your esophageal area telling you that you know this is true, right? And we can schedule a baptism next week and I’ll bring more?

I jest, of course, but only half-jesting. You see, even though here on Quora, I’ve taken a solemn no-proselyting vow, after this post I shall surely have to repent!

The reality is that, as both a full-time missionary, part time ward mission leader, and all-the-time member, I haven’t really done anything. I’ve been around to teach the gospel when people were willing to hear it. I exemplified Christ by doing service, and sometimes that service was baking yummy treats.

Her name was not Sarah. She was a lovely middle-aged woman living in the Hampton Roads area of Virginia. One night, my companion and I stopped to put fuel in our car and I noticed her putting fuel in hers in the island next to ours and she was sobbing.

“Excuse me, but can I help you?” I offered, pulling out a handkerchief and offering it to her.

“Oh!” She burst, “I’m sorry, I really am. It’s nothing, really.” She took the handkerchief and wiped away tears.

My companion, worried that we wouldn’t be home in time for curfew, motioned to the car and I deftly waved him off.

“I’m Elder Dillon, and this is my companion Elder Bousfield, and we’re missionaries for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. We’re here to help however we can.”

“Oh, aren’t you sweet!” Sarah said, “I’m just a mess because my ex just died.”

“I’m sorry to hear that.”

“I loved him so. You wouldn’t think it being my ex, but he really was my best friend.”

“I lost my mom when I was a child. I know exactly how that feels.”

“I haven’t been to church in ages. But the pastor said that he was going to Hell and now I’ll be…is it true?”

“Sarah,” I offered, “we’ve got to get home now, but I don’t believe you or your ex are consigned to Hell.”

“Do you think I’ll see him again?” She sobbed again and I told her to just keep the handkerchief.

“I do. Same as I’ll see my mother. Listen, why don’t you call us at this number,” I handed her our business card, “and we can stop by and discuss this with you. And, if it’ll help, I’ll bring blueberry muffins.”

She smiled through her tears. “God bless you, Elder, and you, Elder,” she said, as we waved and sped off into the night.

The next day, we were surprised to get a call—it doesn’t usually happen. “This is Sarah. We talked last night?”

“Of course! Are you feeling better?”

“I am, thanks to you. You told me to call and you’d come over.”

“Well, yes. I think we have some time this morning. I just need to bake some muffins. How does 10:00 sound?”

“Sounds great.” She told us her address and I started baking.

We showed up at her house promptly at 10:00 with steaming, fresh muffins, and, as she was single and we couldn’t go in (mission rules), we ate them on the porch and shared our understanding of the afterlife. She told us how her church pastor was always preaching hellfire and damnation and how it didn’t feel right to her so she stopped going and we invited her to come to our church and see if it felt different. She thought we were awesome people—can’t disagree there—but it still took a couple of weeks of invitations to get her to attend services and meet others from the branch. We taught her the basics of the gospel and as she came to realize that Hell was not the final resting place of either her beloved ex or herself, she had a great burden lifted off her shoulders. We helped her quit smoking so she could get baptized, and she asked me to baptize her.

I stayed there for a few more months and helped her along, but the branch had great members who welcomed her in and when I left, it was time for more tears, but we both knew she was in good hands.

Now, I pick up a few lessons here:

  1. We’re not shallow. I really was concerned for her that night at the gas station. I wasn’t looking for a convert. I was looking to help someone crying.
  2. We’re honest and not pushy.
  3. We listen and adapt our teaching to what people need to hear. Back in those days, we had a progressive series of discussions that laid out the gospel logically. Thankfully, we listened to the Spirit and tossed those out when we taught Sarah. She needed some meat before milk. Nowadays, I understand, missionaries are trained to be this flexible in their teaching.
  4. Our love for Sarah shone through, not just in muffins, but in everything we did. There was never a question in her mind that we were there for her and would do anything in our power to do, and not because she was a number, but because we genuinely cared.
  5. We introduced her to the local members, so that she had new friends who could be there for her when we moved on.
  6. She did relapse on the smoking. We helped her quit again. As many smokers can tell you, sometimes, it takes several tries. We were patient, loving, and kind.

In truth, though, we didn’t convert her. She was already converted when I saw her. Note how she told us that “it didn’t feel right” in her former church? Well, it felt right to her when we taught her, and when she went to the local branch services. There are some people who are just so prepared that all you have to do is fill the font and she was one of them. She had heard how the Mormons were evil and loved telling her friends on the phone, “Oh, my little Mormon devils are here. Yes, the missionaries. Well, you should come over and listen to them!”

I have no doubt we’ll see each other again.

Leonora Nicolaysen
Ward Missionary, Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints · Author has 3.5K answers and 2.1M answer views · Sep 5 ·

Do Latter-day Saint (LDS) temples have crosses?

No. Jesus died for us. But he was resurrected three days later. We Latter Day Saints preach of His resurrection and His offer of Salvation and His plan of happiness. That is why we don't forbid crosses, but we don't see them as an object of worship.

I was hoping to go to the Temple, tomorrow night, but I just pulled out my Temple Recommend and saw it has expired.

I converted to the LDS, after being a Roman Catholic for over four decades, in 2014. I stepped out of line and was "benched" (placed on probation over pre-marital sex), for six months. Upon restoration of my callings and discussions with my Bishop, I was sent to Temple prep classes and sought my Recommend.

Today is the two year anniversary of my first entry into the Temple, here in Denver. I will not speak of what takes place in there, but I will describe my feelings.

I was a cop in Los Angeles for over 30 years. Whenever I entered a rich person's home I felt out of place, creeped out, undeserving. Temples are beautifully decorated and the furnishings are luxurious (you can usually Google images of various Temples, taken prior to dedication). Entering the Temple, it felt like I BELONGED there. It was THE most peaceful, restful and serene place I've ever experienced. I always look forward to the opportunity to have fellowship with others and feel blessed for a few hours.

What does the LDS think of the FLDS?

I can’t answer for others, but I can answer for myself. Since I lived near the main enclave of FLDS people in Southern Utah and Northern Arizona, and went to college with a few of them, I can give my opinion.

Prior to Warren Jeffs becoming their leader, the FLDS people were somewhat closed and secretive when people came through their communities. They developed this attitude because they couldn’t be sure who was there to spy on them and who was just passing through.

Their leader, the father of Warren Jeffs, wasn’t the despot that Warren is. They did conduct some low key media drives to get more

I can’t answer for others, but I can answer for myself. Since I lived near the main enclave of FLDS people in Southern Utah and Northern Arizona, and went to college with a few of them, I can give my opinion.

Prior to Warren Jeffs becoming their leader, the FLDS people were somewhat closed and secretive when people came through their communities. They developed this attitude because they couldn’t be sure who was there to spy on them and who was just passing through.

Their leader, the father of Warren Jeffs, wasn’t the despot that Warren is. They did conduct some low key media drives to get more converts to expand their population and reduce inter-breeding. While I’m sure there were some child-bride issues, most of the marriages occurred when the bride was at least 16, which was the legal age in Utah and Arizona for a girl to marry with her parents’ consent.

At college, I had classes with a Barlow, a young man with two wives at the time. He was studying education. He was quiet, but respectful. He seemed to love both wives and treated them appropriately.

The other was an older lady. I don’t remember her name. She was much more outspoken. She had been a school teacher and was back in college, studying political science. She, of course, was married to a man with more than one wife. He and his other wives still lived in Hildale or Colorado City. She was attending college 90 miles away with his blessing and probably Jeff’s blessing. She provided additional insight into their community in classroom discussions.

So while I don’t accept or condone the FLDS, I had respect for them. Once Warren Jeffs became their leader, things changed. He became a despot, sex-driven leader. He no longer tried to follow the teachings of the Book of Mormon and Bible and of Joseph Smith and Brigham Young. Instead, it was one big power-fueled ego trip for him and his close associates. They expelled young men from their society so they could marry the younger girls. They controlled everyone. No longer did they act with the best intentions for their people, but for their own gratification.

Polygamy never can be sustained long term. At some point, there are not enough women for every man to have multiple wives. Yet for the FLDS, the only way that a man could reach the highest levels of heaven is to have multiple wives. Without the influx of new women into the society, two things were bound to happen.

  1. Older men would have to take wives from younger generations and thereby deny their own sons the chance to marry. This would eventually lead to political upheavals, which we saw happen beginning in the 1990s and continuing on with the FLDS.
  2. Since their society had a limited number of people—I think around 20K people—and most of the older men having 4 - 7 wives, it doesn’t take too long for in-breeding to happen as the gene pool starts to constrict. This is also happening with the FLDS. There is a much larger number of genetically undesirable traits, i.e., children born with deformities and limited mental abilities among the FLDS than in the US population as a whole.

Little wonder that the Book of Mormon in Jacob 2:23 and 24 actually condemns polygamy. Then in verse 30 he offers an exception to the general rule, “For if I will, saith the Lord of Hosts, raise up seed unto me, I will command my people; otherwise they shall hearken unto these things.”

For those who believe that the LDS church is true and lead by a prophet, Polygamy was reinstated for a limited time to do just that. To raise up a righteous generation. Only 5 - 10% of the men in the main LDS church body during Brigham Young’s time actually practiced polygamy. Yet according to an informal study of LDS students at BYU and repeated at many LDS institutes in the 1960’s and 70’s, it was found that nearly 50% of the active LDS students enrolled in Institute classes or at BYU had an ancestor who came from a Polygamist family.

Yet this was never intended to be a long term practice. This was not understood at the time polygamy was done away with in the LDS church by Wilford Woodruff. It was his declaration that the saints no longer would live this practice that caused the creation of the FLDS church. For nearly a century, they tried to live as their ancestors did during the time of Brigham Young, but with the ascension of Warren Jeffs as their leader, this all changed. Today, I feel sorry for the rank and file of the FLDS people. For their leaders, I only have contempt.

Sushma Sharma

Can Mormons enter a temple (with a recommendation) just for the sake of going in, or can you only enter the temple when there for a ceremony?

I respect the various opinions expressed in the answers to this question, and this is one great thing about being a Latter-day Saint; there’s no indoctrination, and everyone is welcome to interpret the doctrine according to the inspiration of the Holy Spirit.

My mother often goes to the temple with my father (i.e. every other time), who is a temple worker, but as she is legally blind, she cannot read the cards, and so prefers to remain where she does not need to serve.

The Montreal Quebec temple does not have a Chapel, but only a waiting room with a tiny dining room; my mother can often be found

I respect the various opinions expressed in the answers to this question, and this is one great thing about being a Latter-day Saint; there’s no indoctrination, and everyone is welcome to interpret the doctrine according to the inspiration of the Holy Spirit.

My mother often goes to the temple with my father (i.e. every other time), who is a temple worker, but as she is legally blind, she cannot read the cards, and so prefers to remain where she does not need to serve.

The Montreal Quebec temple does not have a Chapel, but only a waiting room with a tiny dining room; my mother can often be found there, and she entertains those who arrive and wait for a session to start.

No one at the temple will ask what you are doing there, unless it is either for small talk, or because they need you somewhere. There is no sign up, or any time limit in being there. Of course, the best place to be waiting is in the Celestial room, but you must have served somewhere in order to enter. That’s the only restriction I know.

One evening, the temple had just opened and everyone but me (about 6 people) were in the opening session. (This is the time when only temple workers can enter past the front desk.) There came one member who was visiting from Columbia, and he was with a non-member friend. As he was early, and seeing nobody around, he asked if I could allow him to tour the temple for his friend. I apologized, and invited him to the lounge. He stayed there for about 15 minutes, then left. He did ask, however, to take a picture in front of the temple, and I gladly helped them with that.

Temples are really a piece of heaven on earth, where everything is done orderly, and without any stress. Just being there is comparable of being alone in the woods… where there is only nature and peace. The difference with that, though, is that there is a sense of purpose in the temple that does not really exist in the wilderness.

To me anyway.

Are Mormon temples open to the public?

Only for “open houses” shortly before the temples are dedicated. Hundreds, if not thousands, of people, including Church members and non-members, come to tour the temples and see the incredibly majestic beauty of them before their doors are only open to Church members with current temple recommends.

However, non-members and members without recommends are allowed to wait in the lobbies during the performing of ordinance work by current temple recommend holders.

Why are Latter-day Saints (“Mormons”) perceived badly?
Originally Answered: Why are Mormons perceived badly?

I’m not Mormon, never have been, and don’t have any interest. But as somebody who has to suffer all kinds of lies, crap and prejudice lobbed against me for being a Catholic, I’m sick and tired of the way people talk about Mormons. (I’ll stick to my guns on this, even though the LDS Church itself has been pretty anti-Catholic historically.)

My brother just moved from New Mexico to Washington. When he parked his U-Haul at a hotel in Orem, Utah, last week, somebody busted the lock off during the night and stole $10,000 worth of musical instruments out of the back.

His girlfriend posts something to

I’m not Mormon, never have been, and don’t have any interest. But as somebody who has to suffer all kinds of lies, crap and prejudice lobbed against me for being a Catholic, I’m sick and tired of the way people talk about Mormons. (I’ll stick to my guns on this, even though the LDS Church itself has been pretty anti-Catholic historically.)

My brother just moved from New Mexico to Washington. When he parked his U-Haul at a hotel in Orem, Utah, last week, somebody busted the lock off during the night and stole $10,000 worth of musical instruments out of the back.

His girlfriend posts something to Facebook about it — and guess what the response is? “Shouldn’t trust those Mormons!”

Give me a break. Do you really think church-going Mormons broke into somebody’s moving van in the middle of the night and stole his stuff?

If people said this about Jews, they’d rightly get slapped down. Increasingly, if you say prejudiced stuff against atheists, you get put in your place pretty fast and that’s as it should be. You can lose your job for saying “Shouldn’t trust those Mexicans” and it’s about time.

But for some reason, it’s still fine to knock on Mormons.

Catholics had to put up with this stuff for generations. (Still do, in fact. I was at a party not long ago and a guy — an atheist — was bragging about walking into a church and taking communion. “Jesus tasted kind of dry. I wanted to spit him out.” You don’t walk into a synagogue and mock Jewish beliefs — they’d throw you out the front door in a second. Same for walking into a mosque. But for too many liberals, it’s “cool” and acceptable to mock Mormons and Catholics and openly profane their beliefs.)

Once upon a time, American Catholics were attacked and their churches and homes burned down. All kinds of lies were (are) spread about them. It took a few hundred thousand Catholics serving honorably in World War II to break that prejudice down. When Al Smith ran for President in 1928 and John F. Kennedy in 1960, people were mortified about a Catholic being in the White House.

Most people think that’s ridiculous today. Catholics are the biggest single denomination in American politics. But guess what: when Mitt Romney — a Mormon — runs for President, same thing happens. “A Mormon in the White House! The horror! Is he going to institute polygamy?! Is he going to ban coffee and liquor?!” (The irony is that most Democrats would sacrifice a limb to have Mitt Romney in the White House today instead of you-know-who.)

My grandmother (who wasn’t a Catholic) thought that priests kept nuns in dungeons as sex slaves. (An idea spread by the Klan when she was growing up in the ‘20s, then pretty much taken up by a lot of “progressives.”) It’s only been since Pope Francis got elected that I don’t have to constantly explain that Catholics aren’t in favor of pedophilia.

The thing is, what Catholics have had to deal with for hundreds of years, Mormons still get shackled with every day. And most people don’t speak up for them.

My dad’s best friend, who used to be a park ranger at Yellowstone, tells the story of coming into a camp one night to make sure fishermen weren’t keeping trout that were less than 12 inches long. These particular campers were a Mormon father and his son. Their fish was 11 3/4 inches long. He confiscated it… then took it back to the ranger’s lodge and ate it himself.

“Wasn’t that wrong? The fish was dead. Why didn’t you just let them keep it?”

His response: “Eh, they were just a bunch of goddamn Mormons.”

I don’t share their beliefs, but Mormon history is full of interesting, strong people who just wanted to do what they thought was right. They aren’t as weird as the Jehovah’s Witnesses, and though I can’t quite wrap my head around some Mormon beliefs, they’re not any weirder than my beliefs as a Catholic. So I leave them alone.

One of my favorite quotes is from the Western historian and novelist Wallace Stegner. Stegner wasn’t Mormon but admired their tenacity.

About the pioneer Mormons who went West, he had this to say:

“That I do not accept the faith that possessed them does not mean I doubt their frequent devotion and heroism in its service. Especially their women. Their women were incredible.”

Are those who are not LDS allowed to enter temples?

Visitors are welcome in our regular meetinghouses. Services start at 9:00 am Sunday. Show up and we’ll happily guide you through our worship.

But our temples, like the temples of the Old and New Testament, are not open to the general public most times, because they are dedicated places of holiness.

Let's look at this logically:

The temple is the dedicated house of the Lord. Do you allow just anyone to go through your house? Don't we usually allow only those with the keys to unlock the door to enter? And we give keys to those we trust to protect and use the house according to our desires?

There is nothing that precludes anyone from doing what is required to gain that trust and earn the key, one requirement of which is joining the church. But those who have not are not welcome except at those times known as “Open houses,” which are relatively rare and occur before the dedication.

It is the same in our own homes as it is with God.

How does a Mormon obtain a temple recommend? How long does it last? How does it work?

Background

First off, just a little background for those who may be less familiar with Mormonism and therefore may not understand exactly what you’re asking.

Members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (the official name of the Mormon church) attend weekly church services on Sundays much like most mainstream Christians. While the format and tone of the Sunday services would seem somewhat different to anyone not familiar with them, they are basically analogous to those held in many other denominations. Background

First off, just a little background for those who may be less familiar with Mormonism and therefore may not understand exactly what you’re asking.

Members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (the official name of the Mormon church) attend weekly church services on Sundays much like most mainstream Christians. While the format and tone of the Sunday services would seem somewhat different to anyone not familiar with them, they are basically analogous to those held in many other denominations. Specifically, the services are held in local chapels and are open to anyone who would like to attend regardless of whether they are members of the church or not, provided they are respectful during their visit.

These Mormon chapels can be found all over the place, in many neighborhoods where there are enough church members to justify them. In Utah and Idaho, there is a high enough density of Mormons that Mormon chapels are more common than McDonald’s and Starbucks franchises. What some people may not be aware of is that in addition to the common chapel buildings, Mormons have bigger, grander buildings known as temples. These temples are not for regular weekly Sunday services, but are reserved for specific ceremonies which can only be attended by members of the Mormon church in good standing. Because of this, in order to enter a Mormon temple, you need a pass card, known as a temple recommend.

Temple Recommends

A temple recommend is issued to members of the Mormon church to allow them to enter a temple and participate in ceremonies performed there. Before receiving a temple recommend, there are some prerequisites a member must follow:

  • They must have been a baptized member of the church for at least one year.
  • They must be an adult, generally at least 18 years old. (There are very specific exceptions where younger members can be granted one-time temporary recommends for the purpose of very specific ceremonies. For example, Mormons generally perform marriages in their temples, and if the couple have children, these children would generally be granted temporary recommends in order to participate in the ceremony. There are other examples, but the age rule generally holds.)
  • They must be an “active” member of the church. This generally means that they attend church services every week as far as they are able, and that they generally participate in church service as they are asked. (Most positions in the local churches are filled by lay people, who are asked to volunteer. Being asked to volunteer for a position is known a “filling a calling” or “being called.” Consistent unwillingness to fill callings when asked could make one deemed unworthy for a temple recommend.)
  • They must pay a full tithe. Faithful Mormons are required to pay 10% of their income to the church as tithing.
  • They must follow the commandments of the Mormon gospel. These include commandments that most Christians would be familiar with, but also include some peculiar to the Mormon church. For example, tobacco, alcohol, coffee, and tea are all forbidden by the church, and using any of these will generally make one unworthy to receive a temple recommend. Sex outside of marriage, masturbation, pornography and other things considered sinful by the Mormon church will also disqualify one from receiving a recommend.

In order to receive a temple recommend, a member has an interview with their bishop (the most local leadership position in the church, roughly equivalent to a pastor in a mainstream Christian church). In this interview, the bishop will assess both whether the member is prepared to attend temple ceremonies, and also whether the member meets the prerequisites listed above. They will generally specifically ask about many of the sins mentioned above, and may bring up anything they know about if the member tries to conceal it. Once this interview is passed, the member will have the same interview again with their stake president, which is a higher up local area leader who generally presides over several bishops.

Once the member has passed both of these interviews, they will receive a recommend which allows them to enter any Mormon temple in the world and participate in the ceremonies. Usually, the first time a member receives a recommend, they will be scheduled to attend their first ceremonies with another more experienced member (often a parent or other relative, when possible). Otherwise, more experienced members can attend on their own as they desire. When a member goes into the temple, there are church members who are assigned to work there (often older, retired members who do not have daily work commitments). Some of these temple workers will man the entrance lobby of the temple, and will check each incoming member for a current and valid temple recommend. Anyone entering without one will generally be turned away, though in extenuating circumstances, it is sometimes possible for the temple to contact a member’s bishop or stake president to confirm that the member does in fact have a valid recommend which they have simply forgotten or misplaced.

Temple recommends are generally good for two years, though they can be revoked by church leadership if the member’s behavior makes them unworthy to attend. Once a recommend expires, the member must go through the two stage interview process described above to receive a new one.

Is the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints sexist?
Originally Answered: Is the Mormon church sexist?

Is the church sexist? Define sexist. According to the dictionary, sexist means “relating to or characterized by prejudice, stereotyping, or discrimination, typically against women, on the basis of sex.”

Is the church prejudiced against women? Do they stereotype them? Do they discriminate against them? No. Are there individuals within the church who are sexist in their thinking? Unfortunately, yes. Tradition and upbringing and other factors still influence us as people, and people are definitely fallible.

Is withholding the priesthood from women sexist? I don’t think so. I think it shows a difference in ways of serving, but not in significance. Granted, we won’t have a woman as president of the church or a member of the quorum of the twelve. But we do have women in high positions in the leadership of the women, girls, and children of the church. These women counsel, advise, and work with the priesthood leadership of the church. These women speak in general conference. Do women serve as missionaries? Yes. Do women serve as temple workers? Yes. Do women officiate in the ordinances of the priesthood within temple walls? Yes.

Now deceased LDS President Gordon B Hinckley spoke about the role of women, explaining, “Eve became God’s final creation, the grand summation of all of the marvelous work that had gone before. . . Man and woman are His creations. Their duality is His design. Their complementary relationships and functions are fundamental to His purposes.”

Other church leaders have explained women’s roles and their place as being divinely intuitive by their very nature as females, a skill men can only gain through the priesthood. While women can, through wickedness, lose that intuitive connection to the divine, men must seek that divine connection through the vehicle of the priesthood.

My husband is currently serving as a bishop in our ward. He told me awhile ago that there are many women in our ward who would make better bishops than he is, including me, (I don’t believe I would be a good bishop—for the record) but if the women took over, the men would be idle and cease growing spiritually and stop serving, while the women will go and serve and grow and love without anyone telling them to.

(Our church is called a volunteer church—but it’s not. It’s by assignment. We receive a calling through prayer, and we have a right to accept or refuse the calling. So every calling comes through the Lord, and it’s a not a matter of us raising our hands and saying, “Oh, my turn! I want to be the president!” It doesn’t work that way. Nor are we paid for our service, although some of the general authorities who are not independently wealthy receive a stipend for their living expenses. So when my husband was called as a bishop, he knew that for the next five or so years, he would be working an additional 20 hours a week as the leader of our ward, unpaid.)

So are we sexist? No, but we do understand gender as something from God that molds our natures and how we think and serve. And while some would define that as a form of sexism, I don’t.

What aspects of Latter-day Saint (“Mormon”) culture run contrary to LDS doctrine?

I presume you mean Utah culture when you say “Mormon” culture. Utah is pretty culturally unique. Most LDS people I've observed outside of Utah have a very different culture, and within Utah, about 50–80% of LDS participate in this unique Utah culture. Thankfully, it's not all of them.

Much has been said about other aspects of it in other answers, so I'll stick to what I have a unique perspective on: divorce and abuse.

I was in an abusive marriage for 20 years. Before the divorce, I was accepted as a member of the ward, but when I got divorced, it was as if I were 8 years old again and had manage

I presume you mean Utah culture when you say “Mormon” culture. Utah is pretty culturally unique. Most LDS people I've observed outside of Utah have a very different culture, and within Utah, about 50–80% of LDS participate in this unique Utah culture. Thankfully, it's not all of them.

Much has been said about other aspects of it in other answers, so I'll stick to what I have a unique perspective on: divorce and abuse.

I was in an abusive marriage for 20 years. Before the divorce, I was accepted as a member of the ward, but when I got divorced, it was as if I were 8 years old again and had managed to contract a bad case of cooties. My ex used his position in the church to spread malicious gossip about me, finely crafted to make sure I was shunned by nearly the entire congregation. My bishop and stake president both refused to address the abuse when I reported it, because they both knew the carefully crafted mask he wore in public.

This is in direct contradiction with church doctrine and policy and the words of the prophets and general authorities on the subject of abuse. After I moved to a new ward, I told my new bishop the exact same things I'd told my old bishop, and inside of 24 hours he was on the phone with the church's legal department to get advice how to report it to the proper civil authorities. I was able to get my sealing to my abuser cancelled within a few weeks of my application. THAT is what church doctrine and policy require. But my old bishop and stake president were too far into the Utah cultural belief that if a person avoids conspicuous sins, they must therefore be righteous in all matters.

Many of my new ward members accepted me, but many did not. I was looked at with suspicion by my Relief Society president. I was treated by many members as if I had a contagious disease, that if they had too much contact with me the divorcing would infect them. One sister even went so far as to call me up specifically to chew me out for working outside the home and “neglecting” my children. This was particularly ironic given that her political views wouldn't have supported me getting any “handouts” from the government to support my kids, leaving working as the only option.

Utah culture needs to change the way it handles divorce and abuse. My experience strengthened my testimony, but for every one like me there are many more who are driven away from the church that should protect them, by these attitudes that the members have in Utah.

Diane Evans

Are Mormon temples open during the week?

Temples of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are generally open Tuesday through Saturday, with some breaks for holidays and vacations.

Hours are different right now due to COVID.

Each temple has a website explaining their days and hours of service.

How can I be prepared to go to the Mormon temple?

Long before attending I had heard that the endowment ceremony was “different”, which really did not bother me; I was used to “different” in Modern Art and in science fiction and I was a fan of both. What I wanted to know was what, precisely, were the covenants I would be asked to make? My parents had taught me to always read the fine print before entering into any contract, so why couldn’t I be told before going into the temple what they were?

My mother gave me what I still consider a great answer. The first part of her answer was that there is no temple principle which does not have a basis in the scriptures. This was somewhat satisfying, but left me wondering if I would be asked to sacrifice my future child, much like Abraham was. But then I reasoned that if true, it had little or no practical application; otherwise I certainly would have noticed odd disappearances of kids in the ward; which was not the case. I considered it more likely that such a requirement did not exist.

The other part of her answer was about trust in the Lord, even when it sometimes means exercising the faith to take a few steps into the unknown before He provides the needed light. Had I seen anything evil in the lives of those who served in the temple and kept their covenants made there? Well, not that I could see; but they were not perfect either. Well, true, she said; just talk to the Lord about it. He can help you feel the peace you need to trust his goodness in making and keeping temple covenants.

In August 1972 I received my endowment in the Salt Lake Temple, but without the benefit of receiving the temple preparation lessons. I have however, and with my wife, since taught those lessons and rejoiced in the endowment of three wonderful couples and the sealing of their beautiful families.

The form and presentation were certainly different and ritually more complex than what I was used to in Sunday sacrament meetings, but not offensive. There was so much to digest and think about, but I just tried to stay close to my father (my "escort"), and to stay in sync with the live presentation and it went just fine; a bit overwhelming, but fine. I rather enjoyed seeing the murals in the Creation, Garden and World rooms; also the large canvas depicting Joseph interpreting the dreams of Pharoah's butler and baker in the Terrestrial room; there just wasn't much time to look very closely. It was a full day. It only took a few more days to get used to wearing the temple garment. The endowment, and all temple experience, continues to be a great learning experience for me. But the learning is not automatic. It requires effort on the learner’s part, just like in school.

I am a little perplexed at the frequent use of the term “blood oaths”. There used to be symbolic representations of violence, but never any blood or vows to exact or to submit to retribution of any kind. I listened very carefully to those now removed parts many, many times. The promise, in my mind, was that I would submit to death at the hands of a wicked person rather than “to cast my pearls before swine”, as it were. What it said to me, was that keeping my covenants is more vital than to save my mortal life. I still believe that.

Some things have changed since 1990, and I still have questions. Nevertheless, I still find great value in attending prayerfully and learning what I can. Here is a more recent visit

Kansas City Temple - 6 Feb 2016

3:45 AM. Alene's obnoxious alarm blares loudly and stays on seemingly forever (probably 10 seconds).

"Are you going to the temple?" She asks.

Hmm; so much I could get done today, maybe I should stay home....

"Yes", I sleepily mumble.

So then, five and a half round trip hours with the ever faithful Steve McDaniel and our young friend Laney Valentine. Plus two endowment sessions and some sealings inside the very prominent building some portray as exclusive, mysterious, cultic and dark.

What was it worth to me, personally?

Besides good conversation with friends. What about the temple experience itself? How did I feel after?

1. Renewed. Totally. I reveled in the light of the setting sun through the clouds over the rolling plain. Even without mountains. "It is glorious and beautiful."

2. Reconnected. To God. To my Savior. To my family. To everyone. That ever lived. Or will ever live. They are God's family. They are my family. "As I have loved you, love one another."

3. Recommitted. Quietly. Happily. To learning. To faith in Jesus. To hope. To a higher, better, more enduring love. Not for things or status. But for the person next to me and their divine spark. To becoming a people of one heart and one mind, and no poor among us. "Feed my sheep."

4. At peace. No worries. No grudges. No guilt trips. God is in charge. Repent. Forgive. Go forward. "Peace I leave with you."

Whenever I reflect on my temple experience, I remember "Did not my heart burn within me?"

I invite all: Put aside the things of this world for awhile. Come to the temple. To the real thing. Not the internet caricature. Come prepared and with humble, prayerful seeking.

"Seek and ye shall find; knock and it shall be opened."

What do Mormons do in temples?

There are plenty of sources to go for this information. In my experience (I’ve seen many, many “debunking mormonism” type stuff) content not released directly by the church is almost always incorrect. Sadly, most of the time it is seemingly done intentionally. Lucky for us, the church has released many resources to tell people what the temple is and what’s done there.

I’ll provide a synopsis based on appropriate material that sums up what we do in temples and why they mean so much to us. Everything I say is “Church approved” (if I say something wrong, please correct me fellow members) but nothi

There are plenty of sources to go for this information. In my experience (I’ve seen many, many “debunking mormonism” type stuff) content not released directly by the church is almost always incorrect. Sadly, most of the time it is seemingly done intentionally. Lucky for us, the church has released many resources to tell people what the temple is and what’s done there.

I’ll provide a synopsis based on appropriate material that sums up what we do in temples and why they mean so much to us. Everything I say is “Church approved” (if I say something wrong, please correct me fellow members) but nothing I say speaks for the church in any official or unofficial way.

So what do we do in temples?

Well, we worship. We participate in ordinances for ourselves and for others. We reflect and meditate. We pray. We try to get close to God.

In the temple, we have a handful of ordinances that are performed by recommend-holding saints as young as 12. Acts in the temple are done either for oneself or on behalf of someone else. Mormons call this “proxy.” We believe that the dead are spiritually alive and capable of accepting the gospel.

We also believe that certain ordinances are essential for doing so. By serving for and in behalf of them by proxy, we grant them the opportunity to receive all promises available to the living. A faithful saint will hopefully perform each ordinance for themselves one time, and thereafter only do it in the service of the dead.

The ordinances are as follows:

  • Baptism and confirmation by proxy
  • Ordination into priesthood (for deceased males)
  • Endowment
    • Initiatory
    • Receiving the endowment (commonly called a “session”)
  • Sealing

I’ll explain each below as well as try to give the reader a picture of what it’s like without demeaning the sacred nature of it.

Proxy Baptism
Baptisms and confirmations for the dead are the only ordinances done by children, and others who have not been “endowed” (more on that later), with the exception of sealings for families converting to the gospel.

Temple baptisms are pretty straightforward. Participants are walked into a font that may look similar to the one above (the oxen represent Ephraim ushering the twelve tribes of Israel). A priesthood holder will then say a prayer including the name of the person for whom the baptism is performed and submerge the participant into the water completely. This is repeated many times, each person usually doing at least a handful of names before finishing.

Priesthood Confirmation

Confirmations simply involve a person sitting in a chair as priesthood holders lay their hands on their head and say a prayer for the deceased person receiving the priesthood. Pretty much just like the image below, but the chairs are more comfy, the surrounding is beautiful and those offering the prayer may have a chair or stool to sit on as well.

Temple Endowment

The endowment consists of two parts, the initiatory and the presentation (session). Initiatories are quick and consist of one being symbolically cleansed and anointed, after which they receive blessings related to their divine heritage. Most members doing initiatories for others will do anywhere from 5–15 at a time, depending on how much time is available.

The session portion of the endowment consists of a presentation of material, including “instruction on how all people can return to the presence of the Lord.”

[1]

Today, most temples use video for certain segments of the presentation. Only a few temples still use actors for the entire thing (“live session”). There are currently multiple videos of the presentation in rotation, all of them are produced in English and later translated into many languages.

(Sidenote: According to rumors I’ve heard, there is a possibility that the church is doing/planning on making films based around certain areas which would contain a more local-looking cast, local language, and stylistic form resembling local style. Just rumors, but pretty interesting stuff to me.)

Other pieces of the ceremony are conducted by temple workers, male and female. The endowment session ends with the participant in the “Celestial Room,” a lounge area beautified to represent heaven. Many people will spend some time there quietly before leaving. Most sessions will take about 2–3 hours total, depending on crowds, etc. and they are performed for only one person at a time.

Temple Sealings

Sealing is the “crowning blessing of the temple.”

[2]
To be “sealed” means that your family is bound together forever. This unity is the goal for our entire human race.

The sealing power is referred to in Matt 16:19: “And I will give thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.”

The ordinance itself is very brief and rather informal compared to other temple work. These occur in “sealing rooms” which have a bunch of chairs, an altar and usually mirrors on opposite walls (the mirrors are not part of the ceremony, but are often used to represent eternity as the mirrors reflect off each other infinitely). The officiator generally offers counsel and some spiritual thoughts, followed by a prayer of blessings promised to the couple (or family) who kneel at the altar while holding hands. The whole thing, including wait time, is usually about an hour or so.

Sealings are bonds that transcend mortal existence. As such, they are held with deep reverence. It’s also important to note that the sealing of families is not dependent on blood kinship. Many LDS families will adopt and seal children, thus creating an eternal family where all are united as one. As I said before, the unity of the human family is paramount to our belief system. We view the work done in the temple with solemnity and see it as a fulfillment of the final promise (as well as the final words) of the Old Testament.

“Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the Lord: And he shall turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers, lest I come and smite the earth with a curse.” - Malachi 4:5–6

To learn more about the sealing power, check out my answer to another question What do Muslims and Christians think of Jews?

Is there a difference between the Mormon religion and the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints?

Yes, there is a difference.

“The Mormon religion” is a nebulous but all-encompassing name given by outsiders and non-believers to the belief system, culture, revelations, truth claims, scripture, and people who believe in The Book of Mormon as being the word of God.

You won’t hear “Mormons” or members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints refer to “the Mormon religion” unless they’re answering a question like yours. Mormon was not the founder of our religion in any way, or even a major figure in our religion. He simply compiled and edited the writings of other prophets on thin metal

Yes, there is a difference.

“The Mormon religion” is a nebulous but all-encompassing name given by outsiders and non-believers to the belief system, culture, revelations, truth claims, scripture, and people who believe in The Book of Mormon as being the word of God.

You won’t hear “Mormons” or members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints refer to “the Mormon religion” unless they’re answering a question like yours. Mormon was not the founder of our religion in any way, or even a major figure in our religion. He simply compiled and edited the writings of other prophets on thin metal plates that “had the appearance of gold” and are thus often referred to as “the golden plates.” Mormon’s son Moroni, who had buried the plates, was then sent by God, as an angel, to a young man of age 17 named Joseph Smith, who was able to translate the plates “by the gift and power of God” into what we know today as The Book of Mormon, Another Witness of Jesus Christ, with a few minor editorial changes in punctuation and wording made over the ensuing 187+ years.

What’s more, “Mormon” was an epithet used against the early latter-day saints (which means “members of Christ’s Church in the latter days” and NOT “very godly people who are deserving of veneration”).

We “Mormons” have come to accept the use of the term rather than constantly rail against those who use it (which is just about everyone who is not a “Mormon”), and even use it ourselves when we refer to “anti-Mormons,” but I will say that I, for one, always appreciate the sensitivity and discernment of anyone not of our faith who refers to us as “latter-day saints” or “LDS” instead of “Mormons.”

To illustrate what I’m talking about, here’s one example from the 1840s of how “Mormon” was a term used to refer to someone who was sub-human. William Reynolds was a participant in the Hawn’s Mill Massacre in which my 4th great grandfather, Thomas McBride, was murdered. A militia man known as "Glaze, of Carroll county" had put a musket up against the skull of 10-year-old Sardius Smith and blew off the top of his head, killing the young boy. Reynolds justified the killing later by stating: "Nits will make lice, and if he had lived he would have become a Mormon."

So perhaps you can see why we latter-day saints will usually say “LDS” instead of “Mormon,” as in the bumper sticker that says “R U LDS 2?”

So anyone who uses the term “the Mormon religion” identifies themselves as being relatively uninformed about LDS theology.

And let me assume that when you say
“the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints,” you mean
“The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.”

That is the human organization comprised of “fellow citizens with the saints,” built on a foundation of prophets and apostles, with Jesus Christ being the chief cornerstone (see Ephesians 2: 19–22).

The Church is not the same thing as the doctrines, beliefs, theology, or practices of the religion you refer to as the “Mormon religion.” It is a subset of what might best be called what Peter called it, namely: the “restitution of all things, which God hath spoken by the mouth of all his holy prophets since the world began.” (Acts 3:21) We LDS simply refer to it all as “the Restoration,” which includes the restored Church and the restored Gospel of Jesus Christ, as well as everything else that was restored to the Earth from all previous ages and dispensations. That’s why we also refer to this era in time as “the Dispensation of the Fullness of Times.”

Why do Latter-day Saints (”Mormons”) refute the Trinity?
Originally Answered: Why do Mormons refute the Trinity?

When I was in 5th grade in Sunday school at a local Baptist church the teacher was trying to teach us about the Trinity. I was just not understanding it. I asked questions over and over and over.

Finally I said “So you’re saying that God turned into Jesus then when Jesus died He turned into the Holy Spirit?” and she said “sort of like that”.

In that moment I knew that I didn’t believe that way. God said many times that Jesus was his Beloved Son. Not another version of Him.

God said “This is my Son with whom I am well pleased”…something like that…Jesus prayed in the Garden Of Gethsemane if it be His will would God, His Father, would remove this cup from Him. If he was God turned into a man who was facing the cross and brutal execution why would He have said what He did?

Over and over and over God and Jesus have communication, the 4 gospels discuss many things that Christ did while he was on earth and when Jesus was talking to the disciples John recorded he asked them “But what about you?” he asked. “Who do you say I am?” John 16:15. Then Simon Peter answered “You are the Messiah, the Son of the living God.” Then Jesus said back to him “…Blessed are you, Simon son of Jonah, for this was not revealed to you by flesh and blood,

but by my Father in heaven.” again, he refers to His father in heaven.

I can’t remember anywhere that Jesus said he was God.

Mormons do believe that Christ was the creator of earth in Genesis. I have heard this taught at other denominations to though so it’s not particular to one denomination.

God lives, He wants us, His children, that He loves with all His heart to learn and grow and become more than just a bunch of spirits/people/beings running around in heaven not knowing much about humanity and free will. So He came up with a plan where we would come to earth, to live, make mistakes, overcome obstacles, find Him for ourselves, and more. Then when we die we can return to be with Him in eternity. But we can’t go back with our sin unforgiven.

So he had to plan the Atonement. He asked who would come to earth and sacrifice themselves. Christ and Lucifer came forward. Lucifer said he’d make us all live and we wouldn’t have choices. Christ said He would leave it in our hands, give us free will. And our Heavenly Father chose Christ’s plan. The Atonement.

Without that Atonement we can’t return to heaven because our sin would still be with us.

After all these things there’s no way I believe that God turned into Jesus then He turned into The Holy Spirit. That’s just not what I think.

I don’t blindly accept anything. When my friend called me and asked me if I’d sing at her Baptism into the LDS church I didn’t know much about the church.

I was happy where I was. I was on the praise and worship team at a full gospel church and driving a bus around the county picking up people who wanted a ride. I was closer to God at that time than I’ve ever been in my life.

I felt whole, fulfilled, deeply happy.

I took the discussions at my friend’s house so that I could see what it was she was doing. I sang at her baptism and enjoyed all the new people I met.

Then the missionaries asked me if I’d commit to being baptized. I said I’d think about it. Never planning on listening to God if He said anything that I didn’t want to hear.

But I prayed, I asked God where do you want me to go to church. I have only felt God so strongly a couple of times in my life. This was one of them. He said “I want you to go to the LDS church”. I was astonished. Surely I was wrong so I asked again and got the same answer.

I was happy where I was and didn’t want to give it up but I followed through and was baptized into the LDS church.

The other times I felt God so strongly was when my guy and I knelt in prayer about us marrying. It was like God hit me over the head with a 2x4, SMACK!

So I married that guy in Stillwater then a year later we were sealed together in the Dallas Temple.

After that my husband and I would go to Dallas to do temple work. I wasn’t sure about it but had a strong feeling that it was spiritual, meaning I didn’t feel anything negative before, during, or after I’d go. I felt the spirit there and accepted it as something we’d be doing. I wasn’t emotionally committed to going or even sure what I was doing was anything more than wishful pretend play. Just following along without truly believing it was what they said it was.

In all my church life I’d been taught you die, then YOU stand in front of God and are accountable for what YOU experienced and what choices YOU made. Nothing could change what you’d done or not done in your ife.

Then one time I was at the Dallas Temple doing sealings and suddenly I felt someone kneel at the prayer alter beside me, I felt the foam knee pad move. I peeking out of the corner of my eye and no one was there.

I closed my eyes and I felt out with my spirit, trying to figure out WHAT was going on. I felt my great grandmother. She was joyful. I believed after that.

I know God’s voice/spirit. I know when it’s Him speaking to me.

So even though I don’t believe every little thing I’m told and I question everything, I know that the Holy Spirit is in this church and that He loves each of us too.

Did God turn into Jesus, come to earth to live and die then be resurrected and become the Holy Spirit? No, I don’t think so. I think God is Himself, that Jesus is His beloved Son, and that the Holy Spirit is a being that comes to us in our deepest time of need and confirms God to us in various ways.

How many temple recommend holding Latter-day Saints (Mormons) do you think there are in the world?

“How many temple recommend holding Latter-day Saints (Mormons) do you think there are in the world?”

There’s a maximum percentage of the membership of the church, based on the age-structure thereof, and a minimum number, based on some positions that are virtually guaranteed to be occupied by temple-recommend holders. Between that, there’s a wild guess based on personal experience.

Age-structure: If the church consisted entirely of adult converts who were baptized at the age of 21 years, went to the temple at 22, and died at 121, then one would expect up to 99% of those people to be current templ

“How many temple recommend holding Latter-day Saints (Mormons) do you think there are in the world?”

There’s a maximum percentage of the membership of the church, based on the age-structure thereof, and a minimum number, based on some positions that are virtually guaranteed to be occupied by temple-recommend holders. Between that, there’s a wild guess based on personal experience.

Age-structure: If the church consisted entirely of adult converts who were baptized at the age of 21 years, went to the temple at 22, and died at 121, then one would expect up to 99% of those people to be current temple-recommend holders.

If the church consisted entirely of families who got married at 21 and had 18 children before the age of 40, with their parents and grandparents, then the majority of church members would be minor children, not old enough for a recommend.

If the church consisted mostly of single, widowed and married-to-nonmember women with up to 18 children each, then an even greater majority of members would be minor children.

So that’s a range from well below 10% to above 90%.

Of course, the church is somewhere in between.

In my current ward, I think we have something like 30 primary-age children and 5 or 10 “youth” (teenagers) on the rolls, out of 300 or so total members; but that’s not because 11-year-olds are dying, or being excommunicated, or having their names removed: it’s because the ward has a university within its boundaries, and a lot of graduate-student families come here with no or a few small children and move away when the parents earn their degrees. I’m sure there are wards elsewhere with more youth than Primary children.

Since the number of convert baptisms per year is consistently larger than the number of new children of record, it may be that membership is somewhat skewed toward adults, at least more than what would be predicted by life-expectancy in a steady state alone.

But I’d say the typical or average ward probably has above 200 adults who are age-eligible for a recommend.

Positions: There are just over 70,000 full-time missionaries.

[1]
Since most missions are for two years or less and the mission interview largely includes the temple-recommend questions, and a mission-president can conduct a recommend interview, it would be highly unusual for a missionary to be without a recommend for long enough to make a dent in that number.

There are just over 30,000 wards and branches, in just over 3,000 stakes. It would be highly unusual for a bishop or his counselors, or a branch president, to be without a recommend, since he is responsible for conducting the first temple-recommend interview; or for the stake president or his counselors to be without one, since they conduct the second.

There is a requirement of a minimum number of “worthy” (although not explicitly “Temple-worthy”) Melchizedek Priesthood holders to form a ward.

A functioning ward has a Ward Council made up of the bishopric, the Elders Quorum president or his delegate, the High Priest Group Leader or his delegate, and the various auxiliary presidents or their delegates: at least six additional people per ward. There’s not an absolute requirement that every member of every presidency be married or currently have a recommend, and often the spouses of some Ward Council members are also on or potential delegates to the council; but there are easily 160,000 members who are on a Ward Council, 300,000 who are counselors in presidencies such that they could be asked to attend Ward Council, and 200,000 who are spouses of one of those groups or a bishopric member but not on the Ward Council themselves, for a total of over 600,000 local-unit-position-related likely temple-recommend holders.

Other observations: With 3,000 members and recommends expiring on a two-year cycle, and the whole Stake Presidency able to conduct interviews, in a stake where 100% of the members held recommends, each presidency member would be conducting 500 interviews a year, on average about 10 a week.

My stake has standing “open” interviews at two locations, four times a month (two weekday, two Sunday). My son’s Boy Scout troop meets down the hall from one of those times and locations. While I’ve seldom explicitly counted, I’d guess that the number of people obtaining recommends in one of those slots is usually between two and six, seldom if ever even close to ten. So that’s definitely above 384 and perhaps about 1152 recommends renewed in those “open” interviews per cycle, almost certainly less than 1920.

The stake presidency also conducts interviews by appointment, but I have less visibility into those. Still, I’m sure those add up over two years; perhaps another 100, perhaps another 500.

To keep recommends current for the whole ward, my bishopric would be conducting on average about three recommend interviews per week. Based on how they actually conduct their schedule, I don’t think, on average, they conduct even one interview per week… so probably between 50 and 100 temple recommend holders in my 300-person ward.

Overall guess: Between 1 million and 3 million, worldwide.

Why did you become a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (a “Mormon”)?
Originally Answered: Why did you become a Mormon?

My parents joined when I was 4. Got baptised at 8. Served a mission at 19.

The usual.

Now “I became X because my parents were” is often downplayed. It is often felt that one must espouse a faith or philosophy or lifestyle or whatever for one’s own reasons.

So I became a Mormon because my parents were.

I remain a Mormon for reasons that are entirely my own…and entirely sufficient for me.

Let me ask you something Rei:

When Peter quotes the prophet Joel in Acts 2:17 — how literally do you take that verse?

17 And it shall come to pass in the last days, saith God, I will pour out of my Spirit upon all flesh: and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, and your young men shall see visions, and your old men shall dream dreams:

I found a Christian Faith in which I have seen this promise made manifest. I follow that Faith.

How should I go about learning about the LDS church and why is it called “Latter day”?

The church runs some websites that are great resources: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the main one, but Mormon.org | What is the Mormon Church and Religion? is probably a better resource for people with questions, as I believe missionaries staff the chat and can answer specific questions.

Of course, the best way is to invite the missionaries over and talk with them. They can answer questions, share their perspectives, and help you connect with other local members of the church.

Oh, and the “Latter-day” is to designate the difference from the Church of Jesus Christ back in Ne

The church runs some websites that are great resources: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the main one, but Mormon.org | What is the Mormon Church and Religion? is probably a better resource for people with questions, as I believe missionaries staff the chat and can answer specific questions.

Of course, the best way is to invite the missionaries over and talk with them. They can answer questions, share their perspectives, and help you connect with other local members of the church.

Oh, and the “Latter-day” is to designate the difference from the Church of Jesus Christ back in New Testament times.

Can a non-Mormon attend a Latter-day Saints (LDS) temple wedding?

No, I am sorry, non-members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints are not able to attend temple ceremonies as the temple is only open to qualified members of the Church.

Members often invite friends and family members who cannot attend the temple to a ring exchange held at a venue or the local chapel where a wedding meal is held. This is done to be as inclusive as possible.

The main take away, from the perspective of the couple being married, is that this ceremony can only be performed in a temple by one having authority. Ultimately, this sealing/wedding is not just for this life, but for eternity. For life weddings, they can be performed in any chapel, court house or garden by one authorized by the state providing you have a marriage license. Sealing for eternity, is authorized by God and such authority to conduct that eternal marriage can only be done in the Church's temples by a High Priest of the temple. Eternal marriages are for the couple getting married and not for family or friends (because they're not getting sealed to the couple). It can be disappointing not to be present…and when expectations of life, tradition or culture are not met…it can be sad and isolating for the person not able to participate. As usual, my advice is not to make it about you. It's nothing personal. It's not your wedding. You're just a witness of a happy event. Participate in as much as you are invited to do and be in the moment.

Smile, shake hands, meet new people, dance and eat. All things Latter-day Saints are good at…and love to do with new friends. Engage.

Why does the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints keep such detailed genealogical records?
Originally Answered: Why does the LDS church keep such detailed genealogical records?

Two things Mormons believe:

  • "families are forever" and
  • "except a man be born of the water... he cannot enter into the kingdom of God."

In other words, the ideal intention of families is to have a chain of one global family stretching back to Adam. This can only be done if you're all in the same place (Heaven.) Jesus said the quote above (http://bible.cc/john/3-5.htm), that baptism is requisite for all to enter into Heaven. Even Jesus was baptized. Later, while talking to a group of Sadducees who didn't believe in an afterlife at all, Paul says "why else are people baptized in proxy for the

Two things Mormons believe:

  • "families are forever" and
  • "except a man be born of the water... he cannot enter into the kingdom of God."

In other words, the ideal intention of families is to have a chain of one global family stretching back to Adam. This can only be done if you're all in the same place (Heaven.) Jesus said the quote above (http://bible.cc/john/3-5.htm), that baptism is requisite for all to enter into Heaven. Even Jesus was baptized. Later, while talking to a group of Sadducees who didn't believe in an afterlife at all, Paul says "why else are people baptized in proxy for the dead, if the dead rise not at all?" (http://bible.cc/1_corinthians/15-29.htm). Anyway, these and many more scriputres lead members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to believe that proxy ordinances (not just baptisms, but marriages also), done by the correct authority, give dead people the opportunity to fulfill this universal requirement in case they didn't have the opportunity when they were alive. Because we can't judge who "had the opportunity," Mormons believe that every person that has ever lived either needs to be baptized or, if it's not possible for some reason (like not having a body when you decide you want to get baptized), everyone needs to have someone else baptized on their behalf. I once worked with a woman who actually medically couldn't get wet. This isn't forcing anyone to become Mormon or making someone Mormon any more than the marriage is eternally sealing together a couple that doesn't want to become married forever. It's just putting the path there in case they, in the afterlife, are considered as not having had sufficient opportunity to choose during their mortal life and thus allowed to accept the proxy in place. These proxy ordinances constitute a major portion of what goes on in Mormon temples (proxy baptisms and marriages, normal/live marriages, and general meditation and prayer.)

Now by policy members of the church only baptize their direct lineal descendants. They don't go submitting names to baptistries for Tupac or Elvis (unless of course they're Lisa Marie Presley.) That requires a lot of genealogical research. The vast majority of people researching in an LDS-sponsored genealogical library aren't LDS (I volunteer in one.) And no research is culled or keylogged from reserachers for the Mormons to secretly baptize. They have a billion names in their own backlog to worry about.

So in summary so far, Mormons are so focused on families that they want to have one world tree stretching back to Adam. (They recognize that academically that's not possible, but they can get a few billion people into the process...) Part of a family becoming eternal is all of them going to Heaven, so performing proxy ordinances, in their doctrine, allows that to happen--if and only if the ancestor accepts the baptism/marriage/ordination.

Did that answer your question?

Colin Jensen
member of The Church of Jesus Christ · Author has 6.4K answers and 12.4M answer views · 7y ·

Is a Temple of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints considered a Church?
Originally Answered: Is a Mormon Temple considered a Church?

No and yes. Mostly No.

We don't call it a church and we don't do things in there that we do in church (we don't meet as a group with whoever shows up from the community to sing or have gospel centered lessons or play basketball or attend a Boy Scout meeting.) But the things we do in the temple are things that others do in their churches (weddings, reflection/prayer/meditation.)

So no we don't consider it a church technically. But yes it is a religious building used for religious purposes, so we wouldn't be offended if, when playing SimCity, "temple" was just a leveled-up "church."

Karen Nance

Can anyone attend LDS temples or only Mormons? How can an outsider enter one without being noticed by church members inside the temple?

Don’t know what happened to him after that. I assume he got escorted out.

But why would you want to? Members who attend for the first time have loved ones who escort them because they don’t know what the heck they’re doing or where to go.

How do Mormons feel about Trump and his style of politics?

LETTER TO ARIZONA MORMONS

Dear Sister or Brother,

My name is Prof. Frank W. Fox. I taught American History at Brigham Young University until my retirement in 2006, and, along with my colleague Clayne Pope, created the university’s American Heritage Program under the guidance of the First Presidency. Some of you may have been my students. I also wrote a biography of President J. Reuben Clark, also under the direction of the First Presidency.

Both of these experiences grew out of my love for our country and my lifelong devotion to American ideals. For those same reasons, I am writing this letter to share with you my deep concern about the approaching election. Although I am a conservative Republican, I will not be voting for Donald Trump in November. I would like to explain why.

For me, the choice is not between Republican or Democratic policies, nor between Liberal or Conservative principles. It is a choice growing out of the very nature and being of our democracy—which is far more fragile than most Americans realize. Democracy depends on more than party preferences or individual interests, it depends on critical qualities of mind and spirit. Our Founding Fathers knew this profound truth in the marrow of their bones.

I have the gravest misgivings about certain of those qualities of mind and spirit. I would like to set down a few of these for your consideration.

First, there is the matter of truth-telling. No President of the United States can make falsehood a common, daily practice. No free government can stand on a foundation of lies. False-speaking in the public square will destroy the soul of America as surely as it destroyed the souls of Italy and Germany before World War II. The first requirement of any would-be dictator is the ability to lie convincingly, and the first attribute of a people he intends to enslave is their willingness to believe his lies.

Second, Mr. Trump has preached fear and divisiveness among the American people, then used these raw emotions to create a mindless, militant personal following. With this private army, which believes every word he utters, he holds the Republicans of both houses under his thumb—some of them in sheer terror— thus destroying the Constitution’s single most important check and balance. This is precisely how democracies have met their end from ancient times to the present.

Third, in a democracy no one can be above the law, not even the President.

Mr. Trump seems to reject this crucial principle. He has violated the laws of the United States in large ways and small ones, often with disastrous results. People have gone to prison for the violations he instigated—one of them cynically pardoned by himself! He was impeached for violating the law and would have been convicted if Senators had been free to vote their consciences.

Fourth, no American patriot can maintain an intimate, secret, and possibly dependent relationship with a foreign adversary. It is absolutely unthinkable. There is overwhelming evidence that our President does in fact have such a relationship with Vladimir Putin, and that this relationship has resulted in the undermining of our most sacred institution, free elections. It is so well documented that it is virtually beyond question.

Finally, no President in our history has been guilty of shirking the Chief Executive’s single most important responsibility—that of protecting the people. President Trump’s handing of the COVID pandemic cannot be seen in any other light than a callous disregard for the safety of the American people in the sole interest of furthering his own political advantage. I have studied his every move in this regard, and I have listened to his every excuse. None of them works.

These things are not “just politics.” They are not incidental and harmless. They are not “fake news.” They are beyond all constitutional limits and outside of all historical precedent. I can scroll through every President from George Washington to Barrack Obama without finding a single instance (including Watergate) of misconduct on this scale.

The death of every democracy begins with a stolen election. The tyrant simply rejects the voice of the people and turns instead to power for its own sake— always claiming that the election was “rigged.” If he cannot win legitimately, he will win by any means available to him, and then just keep right on “winning.” That was what happened to Putin’s Russia.

One final comment. It was recently reported that Vice President Pence, in visiting Arizona, intimated that the General Authorities of the LDS Church were quietly supporting the President. I will bet my eternal salvation against that. The values of patriotism, truthfulness, justice, honor, decency and respect for the law are deeply ingrained in LDS culture. Few church members in full possession of the facts would condone what I have described above.

For these and other reasons, my vote is going to Joe Biden in this election—for his balance, for his wisdom, for his humanity, and more than anything else, for his power to heal. Our country is sorely in need of that.

If any of this touches your heart, please help me to spread this vitally important message. The future of our democracy depends on it.

Sincerely,

Frank W. Fox

What do Mormons think of the musical The Book of Mormon?

So I watched it on Youtube (sorry, not going to pay for that show) and found it to be a decent musical, catchy songs and what-not. I’m not a huge fan of vulgar humor so that kind of turned me off from it. In terms of offensiveness, I honestly was more offended at how they portrayed Africans (particularly Ugandans).

Latter-day Saints have long been satirized, usually inaccurately and in ways which are intentionally hostile, but I was disappointed in all of the African tropes and, frankly, racist humor on display. Even more so, I find it interesting that the outrage mobs so common today have rema

So I watched it on Youtube (sorry, not going to pay for that show) and found it to be a decent musical, catchy songs and what-not. I’m not a huge fan of vulgar humor so that kind of turned me off from it. In terms of offensiveness, I honestly was more offended at how they portrayed Africans (particularly Ugandans).

Latter-day Saints have long been satirized, usually inaccurately and in ways which are intentionally hostile, but I was disappointed in all of the African tropes and, frankly, racist humor on display. Even more so, I find it interesting that the outrage mobs so common today have remained largely silent on this vagrant display of ‘problematic’ behavior.

That said, I still sing parts of some of the songs, and I’m grateful that the play has brought awareness to our faith, even if in a mocking fashion (any publicity is good publicity). I certainly won’t complain that it’s oppressive, given what my forebears experienced, I’m just happy that aggression towards us is largely comedy instead of mobs.

What really stood out to me was how the leadership of the church responded. In this age of unbridled snowflakery, there were no demands that the writers apologize, no boycotts, no organized protests outside of the theaters. None of these things were done by Latter-day Saints or the church nor by anyone else on our behalf. Instead, the church purchased ads. Lots of them.

Ads featuring real members of the faith of all varieties, along with clever text with lighthearted but poignant quips . It showed the attitude of maturity and self-awareness rather than outrage and defensiveness. The example below is particularly relevant to the setting as it pictures Alex Boye, a convert, son of African immigrants to the UK and gifted singer. The whole campaign ran in sync with the church’s “I’m a Mormon…” campaign throughout NYC.

I think that your average church member may not appreciate or care for the musical, but to many, this was simply another chance for us to respond to aggression with love and humor. Show the world that we are not some isolated esoteric but rather, we are your neighbors.

EDIT: I just wanted to update this answer. Since writing it, I had the chance to personally meet Alex Boye (the guy in the picture above). What I can tell you is that he is a truly gifted and amazing person. I met him at a charity where he performed to help promote a program which helps reunify families. He was cordial, sincere and humble. The poor dude spent so much time greeting people that he didn’t even get to finish his dinner yet his attitude was nothing but positive. He also talked about a song that he was inspired to write called “Bend not Break,” which is a powerful message to those contemplating suicide. Brother Boye is a shining example of what members of the church try to be. He is true disciple of Christ and great person.

Ronald Kimmons
Former Missionary in Taiwan at The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormons) (2004–2006) · Author has 14.4K answers and 27.4M answer views · Dec 12 ·
